reviewText: The premise here is that stones can be used to gain possession of a person's soul.  This is shown via five free-thinkers (including two of the girls on the cover) who descend on an abandoned estate in Britain intent on conjuring spirits.  It appears they've come to the right place when a local photographer informs them "this is one of the most haunted places in England."The clothing and attitude is 60s, and much of the movie is brooding music accompanying brooding images.  Only occasionally does the film break the spell by not taking itself so seriously, which I appreciated.So it's "hippies suffer the Blair Witch Project on a Masterpiece Theatre location," which means it's a very different sort of film at first, not quite fiction and not exactly a mood-piece and certainly not a documentary either.  But if you're patient, The Stone turns into a solid horror film, very scary and fun to watch.The abandoned estate is the big star, and it's appropriately creepy and magnificent at the same time.  The gang is visiting to "assist lost souls in moving to the next realm," but of course they have no idea what they're dealing with, and are soon in over their heads.  And it shouldn't be any surprise that the spirits of the dead are none too grateful for the help.All in all, a decent horror movie made in an interesting way, with a couple of really good scares on the journey, (so don't let your guard down).
summary: You don't need to be stoned to enjoy The Stone, but...
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned

reviewText: I love a good horror movie and this fit the bill nicely. The backdrop is a big English house that is pretty creepy. I'll be watching this again with some friends soon. Scary.
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned

reviewText: I'd like to issue a fair warning right off the bat.  If you have been enticed and intrigued by this DVD due to the provocative cover image of three lovely ladies in lingerie, this has nothing whatsoever to do with the actual movie.  "The Stone" is the latest collaboration of extreme indie auteur Philip Gardiner with Chemical Burn Entertainment.  Gardiner may have a specialized following, I'm not sure--but he tends to deal in low budget erotica.  His effort "Cam-Girl," to my mind, is his most successful piece to date as it utilized minimal sets and essentially one actress.  The film needed to be creative to work and, though not perfect, was an interesting example of rogue film making techniques.  Everything got bigger and more convoluted with his "House of Sin"--a film loaded with arty and awkward pretensions amidst the nudity.  These films shared a high quotient of female flesh, so it's fair to say that's his wheelhouse format.  So, I'm not sure whether his latest endeavor will satisfy his conventional fan base.  It has incidental nudity, but can't really be classified in the same erotica category as his previous works.The film starts on a promising note, and it seems that Gardiner is trying something completely new with his narrative style on this film.  But all hope is short lived as the real story begins.  A group of five people arrive at an abandoned estate to commune with spirits.  Want more plotting than that?  Too bad.  Soon they meet an enigmatic stranger, have their possessions sabotaged and stolen, experience visions, undergo possessions, and witness witchcraft ceremonies.  It sounds great, I know, but none of it is particularly well done.  Everyone is under the influence of a strange stone unbeknownst to them--and when they dig it up, things only get more intense.  The various horror conventions don't all fit comfortably with the stone explanation and with the special effects budget of about $5.25, it's just awkward.  Lest I made the film sound exciting, however, most of the screen time is spent with actors walking to a blaring soundtrack.  There is a lot of random walking!It doesn't help that none of the characters is developed in any way.  I might have forgiven other shortcomings had I cared one iota about anyone--but they're all interchangeable.  I was literally counting down the minutes for this to come to an end.  And one more note for future projects.  Just because loud demonic orchestrations are playing over the action doesn't mean you can leave out the action.  More time was spent on the movie's music than on any other aspect--or certainly more than on plotting, character development and special effects.  Try it if you must, but without the constant gratuitous nudity of his other films, I'm not sure what audience this effort will satisfy.  KGHarris, 7/11.
summary: Bashed By This Stone--A Saucy Thriller Missing All Of Its Thrills And Sauciness
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned

reviewText: This film was burdened by too much style that buried the story. While it concentrated on camera angles and a brooding atmosphere, it lost in telling the story. It just becomes a stylized mess that one can't possibly follow or understand what is happening.Often, the camera is filming the cast from a distance or from behind trees. You can see them moving about and doing things, but you can't see exactly what they are doing.  Although the soundtrack is fitting, the audio for the speaking parts is poor.I would rather spend my time watching a good, creepy movie I can understand instead of over-stylized junk.
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned

reviewText: If you don't buy this movie, which you shouldn't, it may be put in a time capsule as a representative element of our current culture. please read the other 1-star review for more detailed advice, thanks.
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned

reviewerName: Read A Review "Book, Movie, and Product Reviews"
reviewText: I love horror movies of all types. I don't care if it's low budget or Hollywood budget. The Stone had an interesting story line where each person was forced to face their inner demons. Humans have some pretty ugly stuff inside them and can be afraid of just about anything. Remember the Stay Puft Marshmallow man in Ghost Busters? In The Stone there isn't anything as silly as that and as the story picks up it grows more intense. The hard music that shows up during the film is something I've come to expect from Philip Gardiner films. Everyone has their unique creative "fingerprint" and this is just one of his. If I saw one of his films without it I'd probably be disappointed!
Title: The Stone: No Soul Unturned
